Organisation de la Commission.Dans sa seance du 23 novembre 1920, 1'Assemblee de la Societe des Nations a adopte la resolution suivante:k Le Conseil est invite a Conner 1'examen de la portee juridique de l'ar-ticle 18 du Pacte a une Commission speciale, qui lui presentera les proposi-tions necessaires dans 1'interet d'une application uniforme de cet article en ce qui concerne la validite des traites. Le Conseil fera un rapport sur la ques-tion a la prochaine Assemblee et la saisira des propositions de la Commission speciale. nComme suite a cette invitation, le Conseil a decide, au cours de sa seance du 21 fevrier 1921, a Paris, wde nommer une commission de juristes charges d'etudier 1'esprit et la portee juridique de 1'article 18 du Pacte et de soumettre au Conseil des propositions en vue du rapport que le Conseil devra presenter a la prochaine Assemblee. aLe Conseil a designe, pour faire partie de cette Commission:Son Excellence M. Etaient presents:M. Scialoja (President), M. Bourquin, Sir Cecil Hurst, M Struycken,M. Gout, assiste de M. Pepin, rempla$ait M. Teixidor, Membre du Secretariat de la Societe des Nations.La Commission, a laquelle M. le Dr van Hamel, directeur de la Section juridi-que, pretait son concours, a designe comme rapporteur M. Bourquin.II. Ordre des Travaux de la Commission.II resulte de l'invitation qui lui a ete adressee par le Conseil que la Commission avait une double tache a remplir. II lui appartenait non seulement de preciser la portee juridique del'article 18du Pacte, tel qu'il est actuellement redige, mais encore LEAGUE OF nations report OF THE COMMITTEE APPOINTED TO STUDY THE SCOPE OF ARTICLE 18 OF THE COVENANT FROM A LEGAL POINT OF VIEW.Geveva, June 28th, 1921.I. Organisation of the Committee.At its meeting on November 23rd, 1920, the Assembly of the League of Nations adopted the following Resolution: "That the Council should be called upon to entrust the examination of the scope of Article 18 of the Covenant from a legal point of view to a Special Committee, which will prepare for the Council all relevant proposals to secure a uniform application of the Article in respect of the validity of Treaties. The Council would then report on the question to the next Assembly, and place before it the proposals of the Specie 1 Committee. "Accordingly, the Council decided at its meeting on February 21st, 1921, "to appoint a Committee of Jurists to study the scope and intentions of Article 18 of the Covenant from the legal point of view, and to submit proposals to enable the Council to report to the next Assembly. "The Council appointed as Members of the Committee:His Excellency M. V. Scialoja, former Italian Foreign Minister (as President),M. Bourquin, Professor of International Law at the University of Brussels,M. Fernandes, Deputy to the Brazilian Parliament,-M. Fromageot, Legal Adviser of the French Foreign Office,Sir Cecil Hurst, Legal Adviser of the British Foreign Office,M. Struycken, State Councillor at The Hague,who all accepted the invitation, with the exception of M. Fernandes.The Committee met at Geneva and began its work on June 24th, 1921. There were present: M. Scialoja (President), M. Bourquin, Sir Cecil Hurst, M. Struycken,M. Gout, assisted by M. Pepin, in place of M. Fromageot. M. Teixidor, Member of the Secretariat of the League of Nations, acted as Secretary to the Committee.The Committee, in whose labours Dr. van Hamel, Director of the Legal Section, also took part, appointed M. Bourquin as its Rapporteur.II. The Work Before the Committee.According to the invitation addressed to it by the Council, the Committee had a double duty before it. It was its task not only io define the legal scope of Article 18 of the Covenant as at present worded, but also to pronounce a view upon the spiritS.d.N. - D. 339. ICO. 8/21. - Imp. Kundig. (Ten degager 1'esprit et de soumettre au Conseil des propositions en vue du rapport a presenter a la prochaine Assemblee.La Commission a estime qu'il convenait de distinguer nettement ces deux aspects de sa mission.Elle s'est done attachee, en premier lieu, a definir la portee juridique de l'ar-ticle 18; elle s'est mise, ensuite, d'accord sur les propositions a soumettre au Conseil.III. Origines de l'Article 18.L'article 18 du Pacte est en relation etroite avec le premier des quatorze points enonces par le President Wilson dans son programme de paix. II vise essentielle-ment a la suppression des traites secrets qui, dans Tordre politique, constituent un danger pour le maintien de la paix. Son but est d'etablir pour les engagements internationaux un large regime de publicite.L'article 21 du projet primitif, qui fut soumis a la Commission du Pacte, lors de sa premiere seance, tenue a 1'hotel Crillon, le 3 fevrier 1919, etait ainsi concu:k Les Hautes Parties contractantes conviennent de faire enregistrer et publier sans delai par le chancelier tous traites 011 conventions interna-tionales passses entre Etats Membres de la Societe. nLe principe de 1'enregistrement obligatoire se trouvait ainsi nettement etabli, mais il est a remarquer que le texte du projet ne,soumettait 1'observation de ce principe a aucune sanction speciale. 'Cest a la septieme seance de la Commission que le President Wilson proposa d'aj outer a 1'article 21 les mots suivants:(( et qu'aueun traite ou engagement international ne sera obligatoire avant cet enregistrement. aOn peut done distinguer deux phases dans 1'elaboration de 1'article 18 actuel. Dans la premiere, les auteurs du Pacte se contentent d'inscrire, parmi les obliga-tions incombant aux Membres de la Societe, celle de faire enregistrer leurs traites ou engagements internationaux; dans la seconde, ils se rallient a 1'idee de renforcer cette obligation par une sanction speciale, venant s'aj outer aux sanctions generates institutes par le Pacte pour assurer' le respect de ses stipulations.IV. Portee juridique de l'article 18.i0 Quels sont les actes qui doivent etre enregistres ? -Le texte de 1'article 18 est formel. II s'applique non seulement aux traites proprement dits, mais a tous les a engagements internationaux m, c'est-a-dire a tous les actes conventionnels qui sont la source d'obligations juridiques internationales.Bien que cet article ait ete parfois interprets comme ne vis ant que les traites ,politiques, la Commission a du reconnaitre que larigueur de ses termes ne permet aucune distinction reposant soit sur la nature des engagements internationaux, soit sur leur -forme, soit sur leur importance, soit sur leur duree, soit sur \a.':qualite des autorites qui les ont conclus.Pour qu'un traite ou engagement international soit soumis a 1'enregistrement obligatoire, il faut mais il suffit qu'une des parties contractantes soit Membre de la Societe des Nations.tjii traite conclu par un Etat Membre de la Societe avec un Etat non Membre doit done etre enregistre. Le texte de 1'article et les travaux preparatoires ne laissent aucun doute a" cet eg arc!.La Commission estime que 1'obligation d'enregistrement s'applique egale-ment au renouvellement. et a la denonciation des traites, ainsi qu'aux actes d'acces-sion dont ils font. 1'objet.Elle est, par contre, d'avis qu'une reconnaissance d'Etat ou de Gouvernement ne doit pas etre assimilee a un engagement international, selon la lettre et 1'esprit de 1'article 18, et echappe, par consequent, a la formalite" de 1'enregistrement. of this Article, and to submit to the Council proposals in view of the report to be laid before the next Assembly.The Committee took the view that it was essential to distinguish clearly be-tween these two aspects of its work.It therefore proceeded in the first place to define the legal scope of Article 18, and then came to a conclusion with regard to the proposals to be laid before the Council.III. The Origins of Article 18.Article 18 of the Covenant is closely connected with the first of the Fourteen Points laid down by President Wilson in his Peace programme, Tts fundamental aim is to suppress secret Treaties, which in the political sphere constitute a danger to the maintenance of peace. It aims at securing a broad system of publicity for international engagements.Article 21 of the original draft, which was laid before the Commission for the Covenant at its first meeting, held rt the Hotel Crillon, in Paris, on February 3rd, 1921, was thus worded:"The flight Contracting Parties agree that any Treaty or international engagement entered into by a State Member of the League shall be forthwith registered with the Chancellor, and as soon as possible published by him. "The principle of compulsory registration was thus clearly laid down, but it is worth noting that the text of the draft did not provide any special sanction for the observance of this principle.It was at the seventh meeting of the Committee that President Wilson proposed to add to Article 21 the following words: '"and that no Treaty or international engagement shall be operative until so registered. "One can thus distinguish two stages in the elaboration of the present Article 18. In the first stage, the authors of the Covenant contented themselves with inscribing among the obligations incumbent on the Members of the League that of registering their Treaties or international engagements; in the second stage, they accepted the idea of strengthening this obligation by a special sanction, over and above the general sanctions provided by the Covenant to ensure respect for its provisions.IV. - The Legal Scope of Article 18.1. Which kind of documents ought to be registered ?The text of Article 18 is explicit. It applies not only to Treaties properly so called but to all "international engagements", that is to say, to all documents which are of a conventional nature and which lesult in international legal obligations.Although this Article has sometimes been interpreted as referring to political Treaties only, the Committee has been forced to recognise that the rigidity of the terms of Article 18, as it stands at present, admits of no distinction, based either on the nature of these international engagements or on their form, their importance, their duration or on the capacity of the authorities who have concluded them.With regard to obligatory registration of a Treaty or international engagement, it is necessary and in the meantime sufficient that one of the Contracting Parties should be a Member of the League of Nations.A treaty concluded between a State Member of the League with a State not a Member of the League must therefore be registered. The text of the Article and the preliminary discussions leave no doubt as to this.The Committee considers that the obligation of registration applies equally to the renewal and denunciation of treaties, as well as to all acts of accession in connec-tion with them.On the other hand, it is of opinion that the recognition of a State or of a Govern-ment must not be regarded as an international engagement according to the letter and spirit of Article 18; and this would, therefore, not be subject to the formality of registration. 2" Quels sont les effets juridiques de I' enregistremcnt? La question doit etre envisagee a deux points de vue.a) Effets de 1'enregistrement a 1'egard de la Societe des Nations.Aux ternies de 1'article 18, le Secretariat doit a publier aussitot que possible)) les traites et engagements internationaux qui ont ete enregistres. Mais 1'enregistre-ment n'emporte pour la Societe aucune autre obligation. Specialement, il ne peut etre considere comme impliquant de la part de la Societe une adhesion quel-quelconque a. des obligations que les actes enregistres dcclareraient mettre a sa charge.b) Efjets de 1'enregistrement a 1'egard des Parties contractantes.La sanction speciale ajoutee au projet primitif sur la proposition du President Wilson, a, pour les parties contractantes, une gravite exceptionnelle. Elle a intro-duit dans le droit international une motion particulierement hardie, en faisant de 1'enregistrement la condition de la force obligatoire des traites.L'enregistrement he se substitue pas a la ratification, mais il devient necessaire pour donner aux traites la plenitude de leurs effets juridiques.Est-ce a dire qu'avant 1'enregistrement, les parties ne sont aucunement liees et qu'il leur est loisible de se soustraire librement aux stipulations convenues, comme on estime generalement qu'elles peuvent le faire ,entre la signature et la ratification du traite ?Telle n'est point, semble-t-il, la portee de 1'article 18.Rien ne demontre, en effet, que les auteurs du Pacte aient entendu porter atteinte a ce point a la valeur juridique du consentement. Des 1'instant ou le consen-tement des parties s'est exprime dans les formes regulieres, le contrat existe et, par consequent, les Puissances' qui l'ont conclu ne sont plus libres d'cchapper unilate-ralement a son empire. Mais, aux termes de 1'article 18, la formalite nouvelle de 1'enregistrement devient necessaire pour que le contrat acquiere sa force obliga-toire positive; elle est une condition qui tient en suspens 1'obligation de remplir les engagements conventionnels. Cet effet de 1'enregistrement est absolu. Ce n'est pas seulement a 1'egard de la Societe des Nations, ni meme a 1'egard des tiers en gene-ral qu'un traite reste depourvu de force obligatoire aussi longtemps qu'il n'a pas ete enregistre, c'est aussi et avec la meme rigueur entre les parties contractantes.La Commission s'est pose la question de savoir si 1'effet de 1'enregistrement pouvait retroagir jusqu'au jour de la conclusion du traite. Les avis ont ete partages sur ce point. Certains membres ont estime qu'etant donne le texte de 1'article t8, la doctrine de la retroactivite pouvait etre difficilement admise. L'article porte que les traites et engagements internationaux doivent etre k immediatement * enregistres et qu'aucun de ces traites ou engagements ne sera obligatoire k avant d'avoir ete enregistre )) (k until so registered *). D'autres ont ete d'avis que ces termes ne sont pas de nature a faire obstacle a 1'idee de la retroactivite.L'enregistrement confere done au traite sa force obligatoire. Faut-il, pour que cet effet se produise, que Tenregistrement ait eu lieu a la requete d'un Membre de la Societe ? II ne semble pas qu'il en soit ainsi. Sans doute, 1'article 18 ne concerne aucunement les traites conclus entre Etats non Membres de la Societe, mais, comme il a ete dit plus haut, la sanction prevue par cet article s'applique aux traites conclus entre Membres et non Membres.Un traite de ce genre n'acquiert force obligatoire quemoyennant son enregistre-ment. .Serait-il logique d'admettre qu'une des parties contractantes se trouverait dans rimpossibilite de rendre executoire le traite qu'elle a conclu, a raison du seul fait qu'elle n'est point Membre de la Societe des Nations, alors que, d'autre part, elle se trouverait liee par ce meme traite, puisque 1'article 18 n'abolit point, comme nous 1'avons vu, la valeur juridique du consentement ? Ce serait inadmissible.II convient d'ailleurs de noter que 1'article 18, dans sa disposition finale, se borne a faire de 1'enregistrement une condition de la force obligatoire des engage-ments ihternationaux, sans exiger que, pour produire ses effets juridiques, l'en-registrement emane d'un Membre de la Societe. II y a lieu, a cet egard, de distinguer clairement:I. Vobligation de faire enregistrer qui ne s'applique necessairement qu'aux Membres de la Societe, etII. les effets juridiques de Venregistrement qui resultent du fait meme de 1'enre-gistrement, abstraction faite de la qualite des personnes qui ont requis cet enregistre-ment.III. Qui peut faire enregistrer?Instituee par le Pacte, Vobligation d'enregistrement ne peut etre imposee qu'aux Membres de la Societe. 2. What are the legal effects of registration?This question must be considered from two points of view:(a) The effects of registration in so far as they concern the League of Nations.According to the terms of Article 18, the Secretariat "shall publish as soon as possible " all treaties and international engagements which have been registered. But the registration imposes no further obligation on the League. In particular, it cannot be considered as involving on the part of the League any adhesion what-soever to the obligations which the registered document may entrust to the League.lb) Effects of the registration in so far as they affect the Contracting Parties.The special sanction which, on President Wilson's suggestion, was added to the original draft is one of exceptional gravity for the Contracting Parties. It has intro-duced into international law a bold notion, by making the act of registration the condition of a treaty's binding force.The Act of registration is not substituted lor the act of ratification, but becomes essential in order to give to Treaties their full legal effect.Does this mean that-before the registration takes place the parties are in no way bound and that they may lawfully and freely denounce the stipulations agreed upon, in the sa.ms way as it is generally held that they can so do during the period which elapses between the signing and the ratification of the Treaty ?This does not seem to result in any way from the terms of Article 18.There is nothing, indeed, to show that the authors of the Covenant had any intention of undermining in this connection the legal value of the consent. The contract exists from the moment that the consent of the parties has been expressed in the proper forms, and consequently the Powers which have concluded it are no longer free to escape unilaterally from its obligations. But, according to Article 18, the new registration formality becomes essential -in order that the contract may acquire its positive binding force; it is a condition which suspends the obligation to fulfil the conventional engagements. This effect of the registration is absolute. It is not only in respect of the League of Nations nor even in respect of third States in general that a Treaty remains without any binding force as long as it has not been registered, but this applies equally, and as strictly, to the Contracting Parties.The Committee has considered the question whether in fact the registration could be regarded as retroactive as from the day on which the Treaty was concluded. Opinion has been divided on this point. Some members consider that, in view of the text of Article 18, the doctrine of retroactivity could hardly be admitted. The Article lays down that treaties and international engagements should be registered "forthwith, " and that no such treaty or engagement shall be binding "until so registered" "avant d'avoir ete enregistre ". Others were of opinion that these terms are not such as to excludej:he idea of retroactivity.The act of registration therefore confers on the Treaty its binding force-Is it necessary, in order to produce this effect, that the registration should have taken place at the request of a Member of the League ? It does not seem that this is the case. No doubt Article 18 does not concern Treaties concluded between States not Members of the League, but, as has been said above, the sanction embodied in this Article applies to treaties concluded between Members and non-Members.A treaty of this nature only acquires binding force by registration. Would it be logical to adopt the view that one of the Contracting Parties would be unable to obtain execution of a treaty concluded by it, simply because it was not a Member of the League of Nations : while, on the other hand, it would remain bound by the terms of the treaty in question, since Article 18 does not, as we have seen, destroy the legal value of the consent ? Such reasoning is inadmissible.It should, moreover, be noted that, according to the final clause of Article 18, registration is merely a condition by the execution of which international agreements acquire binding force, and there is nothing to indicate that such registration must be effected by a Member of the League in order to acquire its full legal effect. In regard to this point a distinction should be drawn between the following:(I) t\\Q obligation to register, which is only compulsory in the case of Members of the League, and(II) the legal consequences of registration, which ensue from the fact of regis-tration, without regard to the position of those who ask for the registration.(III) Who may effect the registration ?The obligation to effect registration, which has been instituted by the Covenant, can be imposed orAy on Members of the League. Les Etats non Membres ne sont pas obliges de faire enregistrer les traites qu'ils ont conclus. Rien ne s'oppose cependant, dans le texte de 1'article 18, a ce que le Secretariat accueille les demandes d'enregistrement que ces Etats peuvent lui adresser. Bien plus, un Etat non Membre qui a conclu un traite avec un Etat Membre de la Societe doit avoir le droit d'exiger. 1'enregistrement, puisqu'a defaut de cet enregistre-ment, le traite resterait depourvu de force obligatoire.La Commission s'est demandee, d'autre part, si le Secretariat pouvait enregistrer d "office, et sans y avoir ete sollicite par aucune des parties contractantes,les traites collectifs conclus sous les auspices de la Societe des Nations et qui sont confies a sa garde. II lui a semble que cette pratique etait en parf aite harmonie avec 1'article 18.V. -Propositions.Les considerations qui precedent ont amene la Commission a cette conviction que 1'article 18, tel qu'il est actuellement redige, entraine des consequences a la fois impraticables et dangereuses.Ce que 1'opinion publique reclame, c'est la publicite des traites qui, par leur portee politique, peuvent affecter 1'harmonie des relations internationales, et, par consequent, la paix du monde. Le texte de 1'article 18 est plus exigeant. II impose la publication de tous les engagements internationaux, sans reserve, sans distinction. Le moindre accord financier, la plus insignifiante convention technique, tombe sous son application a 1'egal du traite d-alliance le plus important. Que la publicite soit de nature a rendre inefficaces certaines clauses d'un traite, qu'elle puisse etre meme dangereuse au point de vue des relations internationales ou du credit d'un des Etats contractants, l'article.18 n'en tient pas compte. Par la meme, il se plie malaisement aux exigences de la vie pratique.Mais les difficultes d'application qu'il suscite proviennent avant tout du carac-tere rigide et mecanique de sa sanction. En privant de force obligatoire tout engage-ment international non enregistre, 1'article 18 est de nature a provoquer des compli-cations juridiques dont il est impossible de mesurer a priori toute la gravite.Les charges qu'il impose des lors aux signataires du Pacte ne laissent pas que d'etre inquietantes.Inquietantes, d'abord, parce qu'elles sont attachees a la qualite de Membre de la Societe des Nations, tandis qu'elles epargnent les autres Etats.Inquietantes, ensuite, parce qu'elles peuvent entraver le developpement des transactions internationales.Inquietantes, enfiri, parce qu'en exigeant trop, elles perdent de leur vertu morale: 1'experience qui a ete faite jusqu'ici prouve que les Membres de la Societe sont loin de se conformer entierement a 1'obligation de 1'article 18. Assurement, Ton est en droit d'esperer que 1'usage de l'em-egistrement des traites se developpera. Dans bien des cas, 1'in execution actuelle de 1'article 18 estdue a un manque d'habitude qui se corrigera facilement. Mais il serait vain de croire que le texte, tel qu'il est redige, puisse faire 1'objet d'une application rigoureuse et complete. Or, n'est-il pas moralement dangereux de laisser s.ubsister des obligations dont on sait qu'elles ne peuvent etre integralement remplies ?En consequence, la Commission est unanimemeht d'avis que, sans porter atteinte a 1'esprit de haute probite internationale dont s'inspire 1'article 18, il est necessaire d'assouplir son armature juridique.Dans cet ordre d'idees, il lui parait que les plus serieux inconvenients du texte actuel disparaitraient, si Ton supprimait les sanctions radicales qu'il edicte quant a la force obligatoire des traites non enregistres. Elle rappelle a. cet egard: i0 Qu'une telle suppression constituerait simplement un retour au systeme du projet primitif; 20 Qu'elle laisserait subsister les autres sanctions prevues par le.Pacte, telle, par exemple, la sanction de 1'article 20.Toutefois,la Commission se rend compte que la valeur de cette solution ne peut etre appreciee au seul point de vue juridique et qu'elle comporte des aspects politiques sur lesquels la Commission n'a point qualite pour se prononcer.Subsidiairement, dans le cas oil la sanction de 1'article 18 serait maintenue, la Commission estime qu'il y aurait lieu d'en temperer la rigueur en consacrant par un texte formel Teffet retroactif de 1'enregistrement. II suffirait de fediger la derniere phrase de 1'article de la facon suivante: States which are not Members are not bound to register treaties concluded by them. There is, however, nothing in the text of Article 18 to prevent the Secreta-proletariat from complying with requests for registration which may be submitted to it by such States. On the contrary, a State which is not a Member and which has concluded a treaty with a State, Member of the League, should be entitled to demand registration, since in default of such registration the treaty would remain without binding force.The Committee subsequently considered the question whether the Secreta-proletariat could ex officio register general treaties concluded under the auspices of the League of Nations and entrusted to its keeping, in the absence of any lequest to this effect on the part of one of the Contracting Parties. The Committee was of opinion that this practice would be perfectly compatible with Article 18.V. Proposals.The preceding arguments convinced the Committee that Article 18, in its pre-sent form, entails consequences which are both impracticable and dangerous',Public opinion desires that a wide publicity should be afforded to treaties which, on account of their political bearings, may affect the harmony of inteirna-tional relations and also therefore the peace of the world. The text of Article 18 requires much more than this. It imposes an obligation for the publication of all international agreements without exception and without distinction. It applies equally to the most unimportant financial agreement, the most insignificant technical convention and to the most important treaty of alliance. Article 18 takes no account of the fact that publicity may be likely to render certain clauses of a treaty ineffective, or may even be dangerous from the point of view of interna-tionsl relations or in regard to the credit of one of the Contracting States. For this reason, therefore, it does not fit in entirely with practical requirements.The difficulties connected with1 its application result,above all,from the rigid and mechanical nature of the sanction attaching to ic. By laying down that any international engagement' which has not been registeied possesses no binding force, Article 18 is calculated to produce legal complications, the seriousness of which it is impossible to estimate in advance. . - -The obligations which it thus imposes upon the signatories of the Covenant cannot fail to cause anxiety.They may cause anxiety, in the first instance, because they are entailed by the status of Membership of the League of Nalions, whereas they do not apply to other States.. They are also a source of anxiety because they may hamper the free develop-ment of international arrangements. .Finally, they are a source of anxiety because, by demanding too much, their moral value is weakened. Experience shows that, up to the present, the Members of the League have by no means fully complied with the obligations of Article 18. No doubt there are grounds for hoping that the practice of registration Of Treaties will become more general. At present, in many instances, the failure to carry out the provisions of Article 18 is due to the lack of established usage, a defect which will tend to disappear. But it would be a mistake to believe that the text of the Article, as now worded, could ever be fully and strictly carried out in practice. Is there not a moral danger in allowing obligations to exist when it is common know-ledge that they cannot be completely fulfilled ?The Committee is unanimously of opinion that, without casting any aspersion on the lofty spirit of international probity which inspires Articles 18, it is necessary to render its legal provisions more adaptable.In this connection, the Committee considers that the most serious objections to the present wording would disappear if the very drastic sanction which it lays down in regard to the binding force of Treaties which have not been registered were omitted. The Committee points out in this connection; (i) that such an omission would simply amount to a return to the method proposed in the original draft;(2) that it would leave in existence the other sanctions which are provided by the Covenant, such as, for instance, those of Article 20.Nevertheless, the Committee recognises that the effect of this solution cannot be regarded safely from the legal point of view, and that it involves political consi-derations On which the Committee is not qualified to pronounce an opinion.In the next place, in case the sanction laid down in Article 18 should be main-tained, the Committee considers that it would be advisable to moderate its severity by stating in explicit terms that the effect of registration is retroactive.
